<!-- Page 1 -->

SSc

*   **Airway**
    *   BxIS
*   **Interstitial**
    *   ILD
    *   NSIP \*
    *   UIP
    *   OP
*   **Pleural**
    *   Plef
    *   Pleural thickening
*   **Vascular**
    *   (I) Pul HTN \*
*   **Others**
    *   ?muscle dysfunction/DRUG / Esophagus
        *   (Dysmotility/dilatation!) \* Aspiration Pneumonia

**LUNG MANIFESTATIONS**
*   Interstitial pulmonary fibrosis
*   Organizing pneumonia
*   Isolated pulmonary vascular disease
*   Aspiration pneumonia (secondary to esophageal dysmotility)
*   Chest wall restriction

Although pleural fibrosis and adhesions are reported to be present in 40% of patients with scleroderma in postmortem studies, clinically apparent pleural thickening or pleural effusions on chest radiographs are considerably less frequent.

---

<!-- Page 2 -->

ILD

(MC CTD $\xrightarrow{\text{running}}$ Pul HTN)
Interstitial lung disease is the **most common** pulmonary complication of scleroderma, occurring in **30% to 100%** of cases.
MC is **NSIP**, **UIP**, rarely, organizing pneumonia reported.

CF, PFT, COMPLICATIONS:
- Insidious, SoB, dry cough, fine Crepts,
* **Pul HTN**, Cor pulmonale, resp failure
- $\downarrow$ FVC, Restrictive Pattern, $\downarrow$ DLCO

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP PACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 3 -->



# CT Chest

*   Disease is localized to the lung periphery, appearing earliest at the bases and posteriorly
*   As disease becomes more advanced, it progresses superiorly, centrally, and anteriorly.
*   Esophageal dilation is common
*   GGOs (reflecting either fine intralobular fibrosis or a more cellular histopathology) or an overtly fibrotic reticular pattern with traction bronchiectasis.
*   Honeycomb change is present in up to one-third of cases
*   A disproportionally greater reduction of the diffusing capacity (DLCO), when compared with lung volumes, most likely indicates the presence of pulmonary arterial hypertension, particularly in the limited cutaneous form of systemic sclerosis.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI BDARM

---

<!-- Page 4 -->

Esophageal dilation
DR. SWARUP KATHI MD FACP EDABM

---

<!-- Page 5 -->

Rx

Immunosuppression has been the mainstay of treatment, with corticosteroids and cyclophosphamide previously being the agents of choice.

In Scleroderma Lung Study II, treatment with mycophenolate mofetil for 24 months was associated with significant improvement in FVC percent predicted, the tolerability and safety profile of mycophenolate mofetil is superior.

In an international, multicenter, randomized, placebo-controlled trial, nintedanib, which was originally approved for the treatment of idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, reduced the annual rate of decline in FVC.

Other drugs: rituximab tocilizumab (more evidence needed)

---

<!-- Page 6 -->



# Pulmonary Vascular Disease

Pulmonary arterial hypertension (WHO Group 1) occurs \vascular involvement in SSc is caused by concentric fibrosis of small arterioles replacing the normal intima and media, but the plexiform lesions and fibrinoid necrosis of idiopathic PAH are not seen.

Isolated vascular disease arises mainly in the limited form of SSc. Typically, there is an isolated reduction in the diffusing capacity as well as progressive hypoxemia.

Treatment with continuous intravenous prostacyclin, PDE5inhibitors, and ERAs have improved quality of life and exercise performance.

Improved survival in isolated pulmonary arterial hypertension > ILD-associated pulmonary hypertension

---

<!-- Page 7 -->



# Aspiration Pneumonia

*   There is a high incidence of **esophageal dilatation** and **decreased peristalsis** (dysmotility) in patients with scleroderma, particularly in the limited variety
*   **Risk of reflux and aspiration** due to **altered peristalsis**, reduced **lower esophageal** pressure, presence of a **hiatal hernia**, gastroparesis, and **autonomic nerve** dysfunction.
*   Aggressive treatment to reduce the risk of **reflux and aspiration**.
*   <u>Behavioral</u> modification and <u>pharmacologic acid suppression</u> are the initial interventions.
*   In refractory situations, **fundoplication** may be considered in the appropriate patient

---

<!-- Page 8 -->



# * POLYMYOSITIS-DERMATOMYOSITIS:

Table 92.5 Polymyositis and Dermatomyositis

**CRITERIA FOR DIAGNOSIS***
*   Symmetrical proximal muscle weakness
*   Muscle biopsy specimen showing myositis
*   Elevation of serum skeletal muscle enzymes
*   Characteristic electromyographic pattern of myositis
*   Typical rash of dermatomyositis

**LUNG MANIFESTATIONS**
*   Interstitial pulmonary fibrosis
*   Acute pneumonitis (with diffuse alveolar damage) *
*   Organizing pneumonia
*   Aspiration pneumonia *
*   Pulmonary vasculitis and alveolar hemorrhage
*   Respiratory muscle weakness *

DR. BHARATH RATHI MD FIP FACI RDARM

---

<!-- Page 9 -->

* Interstitial Lung Disease *
* ILD is the most common problem in up to 32% of patients.
* This has been described as antisynthetase syndrome when associated with an anti-transfer RNA (tRNA) antibody. Of the antisynthetase antibodies, anti-Jo-1, an anti-histidyl-tRNA synthetase, is most commonly identified.
* NSIP is common. A component of OP, admixed with fibrotic abnormalities also seen, => ~ ARDS
* An acute pulmonary presentation
* The lesion is DAD with poor response
  Diffuse Alv. Damage

Table 92.6 Antisynthetase Syndrome *
Patient must have:
* Positive anti-tRNA antibody (Virtual OSCE)

Plus one or more of the following:
* Myositis by Bohan and Peter criteria
* ILD by ATS criteria
* Arthritis by clinical examination, radiographic findings or patient self-report
* Unexplained, persistent fever
* Raynaud phenomenon
* Distal digital fissuring ("mechanic's hands")

---

<!-- Page 10 -->



# Aspiration Pneumonia

Aspiration pneumonia is a common pulmonary complication, occurring in 10% to 20% of patients with polymyositis–dermatomyositis; almost half of the patients complain of dysphagia as well.
This complication results from an inflammatory myositis affecting the striated muscle of the hypopharynx and upper third of the esophagus.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 11 -->



# Respiratory Muscle Dysfunction

*   Hypercapnic respiratory failure requiring assisted ventilation, due to extensive myositis involving the respiratory muscles and diaphragm, is an uncommon event (5% prevalence).
    
    With less extensive involvement of these muscles, however, there is a reduction in cough generation and the potential for the development of hypostatic pneumonia and atelectasis due to mucus plugging.
    
    strain of muscles

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EBARM

---

<!-- Page 12 -->

MCTD

Patients with **mixed** connective-tissue disease have features of **SLE**, **polymyositis**–**dermatomyositis**, and **scleroderma**.
characterized by elevated titers of a specific **antinuclear antibody** directed against **nuclear ribonucleoprotein (anti-RNP)**.

*   Pleural disease
*   Pul HTN
*   ILD
*   Aspiration pneumonia
*   Resp muscle dysfunction

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 13 -->



## Sjögrens syndrome

| Thoracic manifestations | Prevalence |
| :---------------------- | :--------- |
| Airway disease          |            |
| Cough ✔                 | 41-61%#    |
| BHR ✔ _(Handwritten: Bronchial hyperresponsiveness)_ | 42-60%# |
| Bronchiolitis ✔         | 12-24%#    |
| Bronchiectasis ✔        | 7-54%#     |
| Pulmonary infections    | 10-35%#    |

\* Interstitial lung disease
*   Nonspecific interstitial pneumonia (45%¶)
*   Usual interstitial pneumonia (16%¶)
    *   _(Handwritten: a.k.a. Sjögren, HIV, RA)_
*   \* Lymphocytic interstitial pneumonitis (15%¶)
*   Organising pneumonitis (11%#)

**Others pulmonary manifestations in Sjögren's syndrome**
*   Pulmonary amyloidosis (Rare)
*   \* Pulmonary lymphoma (2%¶)
*   Pulmonary embolism and pulmonary hypertension ✔ (Rare)

---

<!-- Page 14 -->



# IPAF
Interstitial Pneumonia with Autoimmune Features
defined by an ATS/ERS taskforce, and termed idiopathic features (IPAF)

To fulfill criteria for IPAF, patients must have
(1) presence of an interstitial pneumonia (by HRCT or surgical lung biopsy).
(2) exclusion of alternative etiologies,
(3) incomplete features of a defined CTD, and
(4) at least one variable from at least two of three domains (clinical, serologic, and morphologic;

IPAF is currently a provisional entity, pending validation by ongoing clinical studies.



## Clinical domain
* Distal digital fissuring (i.e., "mechanic's hands")
* Distal digital tip ulceration
* Inflammatory arthritis or polyarticular morning joint stiffness ≥60 min
* Palmar telangiectasia
* Raynaud phenomenon
* Unexplained digital edema
* Unexplained fixed rash on the digital extensor surfaces (Gottron sign)



## Serologic domain
* ANA ≥ 1:320 titer, diffuse, speckled, homogeneous patterns or ANA nucleolar pattern (any titer) or ANA centromere pattern (any titer)
* RF ≥ 2 × ULN
* Anti-CCP
* Anti-dsDNA
* Anti-Ro (SS-A)
* Anti-La (SS-B)
* Anti-ribonucleoprotein
* Anti-Smith
* Antitopoisomerase (Scl-70)
* Anti-tRNA synthetase (e.g., Jo-1, PL-7, PL-12, others are: EJ, OJ, KS, Zo, TRS)
* Anti-PM-Scl
* Anti-CADM (MDA-5)

## Morphologic domain
* Suggestive radiology patterns by HRCT:
    * NSIP
    * OP
    * NSIP with OP overlap
    * UIP
* Histopathology patterns or features by surgical lung biopsy:
    * NSIP
    * OP
    * NSIP with OP overlap
    * UIP
    * Interstitial lymphoid aggregates with germinal centers
    * Diffuse lymphoplasmacytic infiltration (with or without lymphoid follicles)
* Multicompartment involvement (in addition to IPAF):
    * Pleural effusion or thickening (not otherwise explained)
    * Pericardial effusion or thickening (not otherwise explained)
    * Small airways disease (by PFTs, imaging or pathology)
    * Pulmonary vasculopathy

---

CTD - ILD
Rheumato $\rightarrow$ Pulmonologist $\rightarrow$ Patho $\leftarrow$ Radio $\leftarrow$ Rheumato

**MDD IS MOST IMPORTANT**

DR. SHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

<!-- Page 16 -->

HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS / HP
"EXTRINSIC ALLERGIC ALVEOLITIS"
BIRD FANCIER'S LUNG

s9oinAzzist.com
DR BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 17 -->



# AGENDA

*   DEFINITION
*   ETIO IMMUNO PATHOGENESIS
*   FORMS
*   DIAGNOSTIC WORKUP
*   RADIOLOGY
*   Rx

*(Handwritten note: essay + Clinical Practice)*

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD DNB FIP FACI EDARM
17

---

<!-- Page 18 -->



# DEFINITION
HP is an inflammatory and/or fibrotic disease affecting the lung parenchyma and small airways. It typically results from an immune-mediated reaction provoked by an overt or occult inhaled antigen in susceptible individuals.

---

<!-- Page 19 -->



# ETIOLOGY
? Inhaled Antigen

| Disease | Antigen | Scenario/Source |
|---|---|---|
| **MICROBES** | | |
| Farmer's lung | Thermophilic actinomycetes, *Faeni rectovirgula* | Moldy hay, silage, grain |
| Humidifier lung | Thermooctinomyes vulgaris, *T. sacchari*, *T. candidus* | Contaminated forced air systems, water reservoirs |
| Hot tub lung | Mycobacterium avian complex spp | Contaminated hot tubs |
| Wind instrument lung | Fusarium sp, Penicillium sp, *M. chelonae*, Candida sp, Cryptococcus sp | Contaminated trombone, bagpipe, saxophone |
| Metalworking fluid lung | *M. immunogenum*, Pseudomonas sp | Aerosolized metalworking fluid |
| Summer-type HP | Trichosporum cutaneum | Contaminated old houses |
| Mushroom worker's lung | *T. sacchari* | Mushroom compost |
| Suberosis | *T. viridis*, Aspergillus fumigatus, Pseudomonas spp | Cork molds |
| Esparto lung | Aspergillus fumigatus | Moldy Stipa tenocissima grass |
| Woodworker's lung | *Alternaria* sp wood dusts | Moldy oak, cedar, mahogany |
| **ANIMAL PROTEINS** | | |
| Pigeon breeder's lung | Pigeon droppings, feathers, serum | Pigeons, domestic and environmental |
| Bird fancier's lung | Avian droppings, feathers, serum | Parakeets, budgerigars, love birds, cockatiels, chickens |
| Duvet lung | Avian feathers | Pillows, duvets, sleeping bags stuffed with feathers |
| Animal handler's lung | Rats, gerbils | Urine, pelts, serum, proteins |
| Bat lung | Bat proteins | Bat droppings |
| **CHEMICAL SENSITIZERS** | | |
| Chemical worker's lung | Isocyanates | Spray paints, polyurethane foams, glues |
| Epoxy resin lung | Phthalic anhydride | Heated epoxy resin |
| Pauli's reagent alveolitis | Sodium diazobenzene sulfate | Laboratory reagent |

---

<!-- Page 20 -->



# Immunopathogenesis

3 events
(1) inhalational **antigen** exposure,
(2) host **sensitization** to the antigen, and
(3) **immune-mediated** lung damage. (Type III + IV)

Early reports suggested a role of _immune complexes_ in the development of HP, but the lack of immune complexes in _bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL)_ fluid and the fact that HP develops in the presence of _hypogammaglobulinemia_ indicate this to be an unlikely mechanism.

T cell-mediated _delayed-type hypersensitivity_ appears to play a key role in the pathogenesis of HP. This is supported by the increased number of _T cells in BAL fluid_.

The pathobiology of _fibrotic HP_ is not clear.

After induction by the _antigen_ and (_promoting factors_ that drive _inflammation_), progression factors _promote fibrosis_ and chronicity.

---

<!-- Page 21 -->

```markdown


# HYPERSENSITIVITY PNEUMONITIS / EXTRINSIC ALLERGIC ALVEOLITIS

Characterised by Type III + IV HSR. Serum IgE (N) No peripheral eosinophilia
Biopsy: non caseating granuloma + Cellular bronchiolitis + Interstitial inflammation

Etio pathogenesis

# FORMS / Types

Categorized as **acute**, **subacute**, or **chronic** PREVIOUSLY
Recently **fibrotic** (i.e., mixed inflammatory plus fibrotic or purely fibrotic) or **nonfibrotic** (i.e., **purely inflammatory**)
Few patients may have mixed features; in such circumstances, the categorization is determined by the predominance of features

---
Diagnosis of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis in Adults
An Official ATS/JRS/ALAT Clinical Practice Guideline

---

<!-- Page 23 -->

# Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis : Work up

*   Clinical H/o
*   Exposure H/o
*   HRCT Chest
*   IgG precipitins
*   Bronchoscopy BAL ± biopsy

Combination of ALL

Dr. Bharath kathi MD FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 25 -->



## Radiological Features

*   Initial evaluation – chest xray – bilateral lower lobe nodular opacities
*   HRCT findings for either fibrotic or nonfibrotic HP are categorized as :
    *   Typical
    *   compatible
    *   indeterminate

---

<!-- Page 26 -->



# Non fibrotic HP
_clinical + Exposure H/O_ (handwritten)
(drawing of lungs with dots) (handwritten)

*   The "typical HP" pattern is suggestive of a diagnosis of HP.
*   It requires
    a) at least one HRCT abnormality indicative of _parenchymal infiltration_ and
    b) at least one HRCT abnormality indicative of _small airway disease_, both in a _diffuse_ distribution

HRCT abnormalities indicative of _parenchymal infiltration_: _GGOs_, _Mosaic attenuation_\* (GGOs and Mosaic attenuation are highlighted)
HRCT abnormalities indicative of _small airway disease_: _Ill-defined centrilobular nodules_, _Air trapping_ (Ill-defined centrilobular nodules and Air trapping are highlighted)

_Compatible_ with nonfibrotic HP include uniform GGO, airspace consolidation, the presence of cysts, and variant distribution (_basal_ or _peribronchovascular predominance_).

---

<!-- Page 27 -->

Centrilobular nodules
→ GGO
Non Fibrotic HP
Subacute HP

DR. BHARATH KATRI MD FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 28 -->

Features of the Fibrotic HP Pattern

The typical appearance of fibrotic HP is a combination of
* interstitial fibrosis (coarse reticulation with minimal architectural distortion/honeycombing) along with
* evidence of small airways disease (ill-defined nodules, mosaic attenuation, air trapping) notably exemplified by the three-density sign

---

<!-- Page 29 -->



# THREE DENSITY SIGN

Term coined to replace the "<u>headcheese</u>" sign, as most individuals worldwide do not relate to the headcheese sign

Combination of three attenuations on inspiratory CT images:
* _(Up arrow) High Attenuation_
* _(Circled) White_
* _(Circled) Normal_
* _(Circled) Black_
* _(Down arrow) Low attenuation_

Indicative of a mixed obstructive and infiltrative process:
a. <u>Normal-appearing lung</u>
b. High attenuation (GGO)
    _Ability of that pathology to reduce the intensity of x-ray_
c. ?<u>Hyper Lucent lung</u> (i.e., regions of <u>decreased attenuation</u> and decreased vascular sections)

Sharply demarcated from each other

Highly specific for fibrotic HP; has not been shown to be specific for nonfibrotic HP

Attenuation ( ability to reduce intensity of xray )

---

<!-- Page 30 -->

Figure 2. Three-density pattern. High-resolution computed tomography (A) inspiratory and (B) expiratory images from a patient with hypersensitivity pneumonitis demonstrating the three different densities: high attenuation (ground-glass opacity) (red stars), lucent lung (regions of decreased attenuation and decreased vascular sections) (red arrows), and normal lung (black arrows), which are sharply demarcated from each other.

*(Handwritten annotations on image A:)*
Insp
↑ Black
Normal
White (gas)

*(Handwritten annotations on image B:)*
Expiratory
↑ Black
Normal
White

---

<!-- Page 31 -->



# Laboratory Findings

*   peripheral blood leukocytosis with neutrophilia and without eosinophilia
*   BAL fluid lymphocytosis (typically 30% to 70% of total cells) noted, in both nonfibrotic and fibrotic HP
    *   BAL $\uparrow \frac{CD8}{CD4}$
*   BAL fluid lymphocytes with a relative increase of CD8+ cells, such that the CD4:CD8 ratio is usually less than 1 (normally 2-2.5, as in peripheral blood)
*   serum antibodies (typically IgG, IgM, and IgA) to the offending material detectable
*   Nonspecific markers of inflammation : $\uparrow\uparrow$ ESR, CRP during an acute episode of HP

---

<!-- Page 32 -->



## DIAGNOSTIC CRITERIA: Six significant predictors of HP were identified: ATS 2003

1.  H/o exposure to known Antigen
2.  Presence of serum precipitins against offending antigen
3.  Occurrence of symptoms in 4-8 hrs
4.  Recurrence of symptom on re exposure
5.  weight loss
6.  Insp crepts

**Image Captions:**
*   Kabutar Ja Ja
*   Serum precipitins

Dr Bharath Katti MD DNB FIP FACI FDARM

---

<!-- Page 33 -->

In clinical practice, Recently
3 most important realms for diagnosis include
(1) attempted identification of antigen exposure;
(2) radiologic findings suggestive of HP; and
(3) BAL lymphocytosis.
Clinical history remains a key factor in diagnosis.

DR. BHARATH KATHI MD FIP FACI EDARM

---

<!-- Page 34 -->



# Diagnosis of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis in Adults
An Official ATS/JRS/ALAT Clinical Practice Guideline

**Patient Presentation:** Patient with newly detected interstitial lung abnormalities on chest imaging

**Initial Assessment:**
1.  Exposure assessment* and chest HRCT scan**
2.  BAL with lymphocyte cellular analysis, with or without TBLB***

**Decision Branch:**

*   **Path 1: High-confidence HP Diagnosis**
    *   **If:** Exposure identified AND typical HP pattern on HRCT AND BAL lymphocytosis
    *   Multidisciplinary discussion (✓ *handwritten checkmark*)
    *   **High-confidence diagnosis of HP**
    *   *(Handwritten summary for this path: E⊕, CT⊕, BAL⊕ ⇓ MDD HP)*

*   **Path 2: Unclear Diagnosis / Further Investigation**
    *   **If:** Any of the above criteria are not met (*handwritten: Any⊖*) OR All other combinations of exposure, HRCT, BAL, and TBLB findings
        *   *(Handwritten notes/examples for this path: CT (crossed out) BAL (L)⊕, exposure (HO)⊕, E⊕)*
    *   ? Unclear diagnosis
        *   *(If unclear, reconsider exposures (circled, handwritten))*
    *   Multidisciplinary discussion (boxed)
        *   *(Handwritten note: Cryo biopsy)*
    *   Consider TBLC* (highlighted in yellow, *handwritten: Transbronchial lung cryobiopsy*) or SLB** (highlighted in yellow, *handwritten: Surgical lung biopsy*)
        *   *(Handwritten arrow from "Any⊖" (from Path 1 criteria) points to "Biops" (handwritten) which points to "HP" (handwritten))*
    *   Multidisciplinary discussion (boxed)
    *   **Diagnosis of HP**

---

<!-- Page 35 -->



# Management of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis

(Handwritten: Case to case basis)

1.  **Comprehensive antigen remediation, if identified** (Handwritten circle around "antigen")

    *   **Left Branch (Handwritten: Stable No Rx)**
        *   **Predominantly inflammatory disease (GGO on HRCT, no fibrosis), mild and stable clinical presentation** (Underlined: GGO on HRCT, mild and stable)
            *   Monitor, no treatment required (Underlined)
            *   Lifetime Ag avoidance (Underlined)

    *   **Middle Branch (Handwritten: Hypoxemia => Steroid)**
        *   **Predominantly inflammatory disease (GGO on HRCT, BAL lymphocytosis), severe clinical presentation (hypoxemia)** (Underlined: Predominantly inflammatory, GGO on HRCT, hypoxemia)
            *   Consider oral steroids (e.g., prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg/day x 4-6 weeks, with taper for total 3 mo) (Underlined: 4-6 weeks, total 3 mo)
            *   Clinical reassessment at 3 mo (Underlined: 3 mo)
            *   Lifetime Ag avoidance (Underlined)

    *   **Right Branch (Handwritten: fibrosis)**
        *   **Predominantly fibrotic disease (fibrosis on HRCT, no BAL lymphocytosis), severe clinical presentation (hypoxemia)** (Underlined: fibrosis on HRCT, hypoxemia)
            *   Consider oral steroids (e.g., prednisone 0.5-1 mg/kg/day x 4-6 weeks, with taper for total 3 mo)
            *   Consider initiating steroid-sparing drug (e.g., MMF or AZA) (Underlined: MMF or AZA)
            *   Clinical reassessment at 3 mo
            *   Lifetime Ag avoidance
        *   Consider antifibrotic therapy
        *   Supportive therapy, O2 + Rehab (Underlined: O2 + Rehab)
        *   Refer to lung transplant, if appropriate (Underlined: lung transplant)
        *   (Handwritten next to this branch: Anti fibrotic + Supportive + Lung transplant)

---
